awd_titl_txt: GRC/GRS Venom Evolution, Function and Biomedical Applications: Bridging Gaps in Venom Research: From Ecology and Evolution to Socio-Economic Impacts
awd_abstract_narration:
The Gordon Research Conference (GRC) and Gordon Research Seminar (GRS) on Venom Evolution, Function and Biomedical Applications represent unique international forums to share cutting-edge research on the evolution, function, and applications of venom. Animal venoms are key evolutionary adaptations that have originated independently in many animal lineages to assist in defense, predation, and competition. Venoms are some of the most complex secretions known in nature and are made up of toxins and other bioactive compounds whose molecular structure and targets are often similar throughout the animal kingdom. These features make venoms excellent systems to answer fundamental questions in evolutionary biology, and these toxins are untapped resources of novel compounds with great potential for biotechnological applications including drug leads and pesticides. The Venom GRC and GRS will bring together senior and junior researchers from academia and industry to define key areas of venom research, establish collaborations to advance the field, and evaluate challenges and opportunities to achieve a greater impact in basic and applied science. This award will specifically enable early career researchers, including graduate students, postdocs, women and other underrepresented minorities in science, to attend both the 2022 Venom GRS (August 6-7, 2022) and GRC (August 7-12, 2022). This will provide an excellent platform for early career researchers to share their work, while establishing connections and international networks leading to collaborations that will advance venom research. The GRS specifically will aid in this endeavor by concluding with a panel of mentors from industry and academia to offer career advice and discuss their background with attendees, fostering the careers of the future leaders of venom research. 

The specific theme of the 2022 Venom GRC and GRS is “Bridging Gaps in Venom Research: From Ecology and Evolution to Socio-Economic Impacts”. The combined programs include 13 topical sessions featuring invited speakers and selected presentations by both early career and established researchers, and six interactive poster sessions to provide participants with a world-class view of the interdisciplinarity of venom research. The sessions highlight some of the most important challenges and opportunities for collaboration and interdisciplinary innovation in the venom field and include “Functional Ecology and Biodiversity of Venom”, “Emerging Models in Venom Research”, “Toxin Structure and Function” and “Biomedical and Pesticidal Applications of Venom” among others. The guiding principle of GRC and GRS is to encourage communication, discussion of ideas and unpublished results at the frontier of the field, emphasizing personal interactions and community-building. As such, these GRC and GRS meetings are an outstanding opportunity to build a strong, diverse and cohesive venom research community able to cultivate innovative approaches to address the most important challenges and opportunities for the field of venom research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Summary:

The Gordon Research Seminar (GRS) and Gordon Research Conference (GRC) on Venom Evolution, Function and Biomedical Applications took place on August 6-12, 2022 at Mount Snow in West Dover, VT, USA. Our GRS was chaired by Dr. Aida Verdes (Postdoc, National Museum of Natural Sciences, Spanish Research Council) and Dr. Micaiah Ward (Postdoc, Regeneron Pharmaceuticals), and our GRC was chaired by Dr. Ashlee Rowe (University of Oklahoma) and Dr. Glenn King (University of Queensland).

The Venom GRS was a unique forum for graduate students, postdocs, and other scientists with comparable levels of experience and education to present and exchange new data and cutting-edge ideas, with a focus on connecting key areas in our field, from basic research to venom-derived applications and their multiple socio-economic impacts. Our program featured three sessions of oral presentations comprised of 19 speakers and three discussion leaders covering the topics of Ecology and Evolution of Venomous Taxa, Venom Function and Characterization, and Biomedical and Pesticidal Applications of Venom. In addition to oral presentations, all 36 graduate student and postdoc participants were able to present their work in our two poster sessions where we were able to engage in lively scientific discussion in a relaxed atmosphere.

The Venoms GRC provided a comprehensive program of 39 talks across nine scientific sessions, with robust discussions within each session led by Discussion Leaders with expertise in the subject area. The scientific talks ranged from ecological and evolutionary aspects of venom to therapeutic and agricultural applications, as well as the clinical and socio-economic impacts of envenomation. In addition to oral presentations, the GRC program included four poster sessions at which students, postdocs and PIs presented a total of 60 posters in an atmosphere that encouraged discussion and exchange of ideas. Many new collaborations evolved from these poster discussions.

Our scheduled program, in combination with social activities and ample free time, allowed our attendees to interact in both professional and casual capacity, facilitating the start of scientific collaborations, the forging of friendships, and establishing the foundation of an international, cross-disciplinary network of next-generation venom researchers.

Thanks to our generous contributors including the NSF, the 2022 GRS and GRC on Venom Evolution, Function and Biomedical Applications was able to provide full or partial registration and travel support to every graduate student, postdoc and minority who applied for financial aid, truly making the 2022 Venom GRS and GRC financially accessible to all attendees.

Mentorship Component:

The GRS hosted an early career mentoring session with a panel of five distinguished venom researchers from both academia and industry, where participants were able to freely ask questions, hear career-forming stories, and receive invaluable advice from those who have been in their shoes before and are now established researchers with successful careers. The panel included five distinguished researchers in the venom field, with diverse backgrounds in terms of expertise and professional trajectory, career stage, gender and ethnicity and provided participants with an impactful mentoring experience that represents the wide diversity of research and researchers in the venom field. Based on follow up discussions with attendees and mentors who participated in the early career mentoring session, this was a highlight of the conference and provided early career researchers with advice and guidance they had been looking for, as well as more confidence and connections in their career paths moving forward.

Diversity and Inclusion efforts:

We made every effort to achieve a diverse and balanced representation of gender, culture, ethnicity, career stage and scientific discipline/organism at both the Venoms GRS and GRC. Invited speakers and discussion leaders were chosen with this in mind, as well as those selected for oral presentations from submitted abstracts for both the GRS and GRC. To better ensure a diverse pool of conference attendees, several graduate students and postdocs from the venom research community volunteered to form a Social Media Ambassador group to promote the Venoms GRS and GRC, inform the community about financial aid opportunities, and engage in venom-related scientific outreach on a weekly basis.

The GRC program included a "Power Hour" led by Nancy Gray, President and CEO of the Gordon Research Conferences, which addressed issues of diversity and inclusion at scientific meetings. Although this was an optional portion of our program, the Power Hour was well attended and allowed participants to form focus groups where different real-life diversity and inclusion scenarios were provided and discussed openly and honestly. These discussions allowed individuals to hear personal perspectives from others with very different cultural backgrounds, and engage in meaningful and respectful dialog surrounding these topics. Not only was this enlightening during the Power Hour for those who participated, but these conversations were continued throughout the week of the conference and contributed to the overall inclusive and respectful environment we strived for.
